q: What are the 7 layers of the OSI Model from Top to Bottom?
a: Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, Physical. (Mnemonic: All People Seem To Need Data Processing)

q: What is the main difference between the OSI Model and the TCP/IP Model?
a: OSI is a theoretical 7-layer model. TCP/IP is a practical 4-layer model (Application, Transport, Internet, Network Interface) used in real-world networking.

q: What is a PDU (Protocol Data Unit) called at the Transport Layer?
a: Segment (for TCP) or Datagram (for UDP).

q: What is a PDU called at the Network Layer?
a: Packet.

q: What is a PDU called at the Data Link Layer?
a: Frame.
Simplex: One-way only (e.g., Radio). Half-Duplex: Both ways, but one at a time (e.g., Walkie-Talkie). Full-Duplex: Both ways simultaneously (e.g., Telephone).
Media Access Control address. A unique 48-bit hardware identifier assigned to a network interface card (NIC) for communication on the physical network segment.
Address Resolution Protocol. It resolves a known IP address to a physical MAC address.

q: How does a Switch differ from a Hub?
a: A Hub broadcasts data to all ports (Layer 1). A Switch intelligently forwards data only to the specific destination MAC address (Layer 2).
Virtual LAN. It logically groups devices on different physical LANs into a single broadcast domain to improve security and performance.

q: What is the difference between IPv4 and IPv6?
a: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses (dotted decimal). IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses (hexadecimal) and provides a vastly larger address space.
A 32-bit number that masks an IP address to separate the network address from the host address.
Classless Inter-Domain Routing. A method for allocating IP addresses and IP routing that replaces the older class-based system (Class A, B, C).
127.0.0.1 (IPv4) or ::1 (IPv6). Traffic sent to this address loops back to the sending machine; used for testing the network stack.
Network Address Translation. It allows a private network to share a single public IP address for accessing the internet.
Internet Control Message Protocol. Used for diagnostics and error reporting (e.g., Ping, Destination Unreachable).
A field in an IP packet that prevents infinite loops. It is decremented by 1 at every router hop; the packet is discarded when TTL reaches 0.

q: Difference between Unicast, Multicast, and Broadcast.
a: Unicast: One-to-one. Multicast: One-to-many (specific group). Broadcast: One-to-all (entire network).

q: What are the key differences between TCP and UDP?
a: TCP is connection-oriented, reliable, ordered, and heavy. UDP is connectionless, unreliable, unordered, and lightweight.
1. Client sends SYN. 2. Server responds with SYN-ACK. 3. Client sends ACK. This establishes a reliable connection.

q: What is Flow Control in TCP?
a: A mechanism (like Sliding Window) to prevent the sender from overwhelming the receiver with too much data at once.

q: What is Congestion Control in TCP?
a: Algorithms (like Slow Start, Congestion Avoidance) to prevent the sender from overwhelming the network itself.

q: What happens in the TCP Four-Way Termination?
a: 1. FIN from initiator. 2. ACK from receiver. 3. FIN from receiver. 4. ACK from initiator. (Connection closed).
One endpoint of a two-way communication link between two programs running on the network, identified by an IP address and a Port number.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. Automatically assigns IP addresses and network configuration to devices (DORA process: Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge).
Domain Name System. Translates human-readable domain names (example.com) into IP addresses (93.184.216.34).

q: What is an 'A' Record in DNS?
a: Maps a hostname to an IPv4 address.

q: What is a 'CNAME' Record in DNS?
a: Canonical Name. Maps an alias domain name to another primary domain name.
HTTPS is HTTP encrypted using TLS/SSL. HTTP sends data in plaintext (port 80), HTTPS sends encrypted data (port 443).
GET (retrieve), POST (submit), PUT (update/replace), PATCH (partial update), DELETE (remove), HEAD (headers only).

q: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
a: PUT replaces the entire resource. PATCH applies partial modifications to a resource.

q: What does Idempotent mean in HTTP?
a: An operation is idempotent if making the same request multiple times produces the same result (e.g., GET, PUT, DELETE are idempotent; POST is not).
200: OK (Request succeeded). 201: Created (Request succeeded and a new resource was created).
301: Moved Permanently (SEO passes to new URL). 302: Found/Moved Temporarily.
401: Unauthorized (Authentication required). 403: Forbidden (Authenticated but not allowed).
500: Internal Server Error (Server crashed/bug). 503: Service Unavailable (Overloaded or maintenance).
A small piece of data stored on the client-side by the web browser, sent back to the server with every request to maintain state.

q: What is the purpose of the 'User-Agent' header?
a: Identifies the client software (browser, OS, device) to the server.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol. Used for SENDING emails between servers.

q: What are POP3 and IMAP used for?
a: Retrieving emails. POP3 downloads and deletes from server (usually). IMAP syncs with server (emails stay on server).

q: What is FTP? Which ports does it use?
a: File Transfer Protocol. Uses Port 21 (Command) and Port 20 (Data).
Secure Shell. A protocol for secure remote login and other secure network services over an insecure network (Port 22).

q: What is the difference between a Forward Proxy and a Reverse Proxy?
a: Forward Proxy acts on behalf of the client (anonymity). Reverse Proxy acts on behalf of the server (load balancing, caching, security).
A device or software that distributes network or application traffic across a number of servers to increase capacity and reliability.

q: Explain Layer 4 vs Layer 7 Load Balancing.
a: Layer 4 (Transport): Routes based on IP and Port. Layer 7 (Application): Routes based on content (URL, Headers, Cookies).
Content Delivery Network. A network of distributed servers that deliver web content to users based on their geographic location.
A routing methodology where multiple servers share the same IP address, and the network routes the request to the topologically nearest one.
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules.
Distributed Denial of Service. Multiple compromised systems attack a target to flood it with traffic and make it unavailable.
An encrypted connection over the internet between a device and a network, ensuring data privacy.
Symmetric: Same key for encryption and decryption. Asymmetric: Public key to encrypt, Private key to decrypt.
The process where client and server exchange keys and establish a secure, encrypted session before sending data.
An attacker secretly intercepts and possibly alters communications between two parties who believe they are communicating directly.
Uses ICMP Echo Request/Reply to test reachability and measure round-trip time to a host.
Shows the path (hops) packets take to a destination by manipulating the TTL field.
A network protocol analyzer used for capturing and inspecting packets in real-time.
Network Statistics. Displays active connections, routing tables, and interface stats.

q: What happens when you type 'google.com' in a browser?
a: 1. DNS Lookup 2. TCP Handshake 3. HTTP/HTTPS Request 4. Server Response 5. Browser Rendering.

q: Why would you choose UDP over TCP for a video game?
a: Real-time games prefer speed over reliability. Dropped packets are better than delayed packets (lag).

q: What is the difference between Bandwidth and Latency?
a: Bandwidth is the capacity (width of the pipe). Latency is the delay (time to travel the pipe).
The actual rate of successful data transfer over a channel (often less than bandwidth due to errors/overhead).
The variation in packet arrival time (latency). High jitter causes buffering in streaming.
Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection. A method used in Ethernet to handle data collisions.
The router interface IP that a device sends traffic to when the destination is outside the local network.
Maximum Transmission Unit. The largest packet size that can be transmitted over a network interface (usually 1500 bytes for Ethernet).
Splitting a packet into smaller pieces if it exceeds the MTU of the network.

q: Difference between Static and Dynamic Routing.
a: Static: Administrator manually defines paths. Dynamic: Routers exchange info (OSPF, BGP) to automatically find best paths.
Open Shortest Path First. An Interior Gateway Protocol (IGP) using Link State algorithms.
Border Gateway Protocol. The Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP) used to route traffic between different Autonomous Systems (AS) on the internet.
A collection of connected IP routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators (e.g., an ISP).
A protocol providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection (persistent).
WebSockets: True two-way persistent connection. Long Polling: Client requests, server holds until data is available, then closes. Client re-requests.
A standard allowing servers to push data to web pages over HTTP (One-way: Server -> Client).
Allows the same TCP connection to remain open for multiple HTTP requests, reducing latency.
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. A mechanism allowing resources on a web page to be requested from another domain.
An attack where malicious scripts are injected into trusted websites.
An attack where malicious SQL statements are inserted into entry fields for execution (e.g., dumping the database).
A hashing technique used in distributed systems/load balancing to minimize reorganization when nodes are added or removed.
In a distributed system, you can only pick 2: Consistency, Availability, Partition Tolerance.

q: What is the sliding window protocol?
a: A flow control protocol where the sender can send multiple frames before waiting for an acknowledgment.
Name Server Lookup. A tool to query DNS servers to find IP addresses or other DNS records.
Client URL. A command-line tool for transferring data using various network protocols (HTTP, FTP, etc.).
All nodes connect independently to a central hub or switch. If the central device fails, the network fails.
Every node is connected to every other node (Full Mesh). Expensive but highest redundancy.
Network Interface Card. Hardware that allows a computer to connect to a network.

q: What is the purpose of MIME types?
a: Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions. It indicates the nature and format of a document/file (e.g., text/html, application/json).
A major revision of HTTP. It adds Multiplexing (multiple requests over one connection), Header Compression, and Server Push.
The next generation of HTTP, based on the QUIC protocol (over UDP), designed to reduce latency and solve head-of-line blocking.
Creating IP packets with a false source IP address to hide the sender's identity or impersonate another system.
A DDoS attack where attackers send a flood of SYN requests to consume server resources, rendering it unresponsive.

q: What is a Private IP Address?
a: IP addresses reserved for internal use (LANs) and not routable on the public internet (e.g., 192.168.x.x).
Automatic Private IP Addressing. Windows assigns a 169.254.x.x address when a DHCP server is unavailable.
The process of wrapping data with protocol headers/trailers as it moves down the OSI layers.
The process of removing headers/trailers as data moves up the OSI layers at the receiver.
The number of routers a packet must pass through to reach its destination.
The state where all routers in a network agree on the optimal paths to all destinations.
Internet Protocol Security. A suite of protocols to secure IP communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet.
Uniform Resource Locator. A reference to a web resource that specifies its location and the mechanism to retrieve it.
Controlling the rate of traffic sent or received by a network interface or application to prevent abuse.
A load balancing technique where a user's session is bound to a specific server for the duration of the session.
A Layer 1 device that regenerates and retransmits signals to extend the range of a network.
A Layer 2 device that connects two network segments and filters traffic based on MAC addresses.
Redirecting communication requests from one address and port number to another while packets are traversing a network gateway.
A DNS service that directs traffic to different IP addresses based on the geographic location of the client.
An old network protocol for bidirectional text communication. Insecure because it sends data in plaintext.
An electronic document used to prove the ownership of a public key (used in SSL/TLS).
A security process requiring two different forms of identification (e.g., password + SMS code).
Remote Procedure Call. A protocol that allows a program to execute a procedure on another computer as if it were local.
REST: Architectural style, lightweight, uses JSON/XML, stateless. SOAP: Protocol, heavy, uses XML, strict standards.

q: How do you troubleshoot a 'Connection Refused' error?
a: Check if the server application is running, check if it's listening on the correct port, and check firewall rules.

q: How do you troubleshoot high latency?
a: Use ping/traceroute to find bottlenecks, check bandwidth usage, check for packet loss, and inspect server load.
A performance issue where a line of packets is held up by the processing of the first packet.

q: What is a Salt in password hashing?
a: Random data added to a password before hashing to protect against dictionary attacks and rainbow tables.
Mail Exchange record. Specifies the mail server responsible for accepting email on behalf of a domain.
Start of Authority. Contains administrative information about the zone (serial number, admin email, refresh rates).
Structuring an application as a collection of loosely coupled services, often communicating over HTTP/REST.
The process of automatically detecting devices and services on a computer network.
A logical division of a computer network where all nodes can reach each other by broadcast at the data link layer.
A network segment where data packets can collide with one another when being sent (common in Hubs).
A means of improving the efficiency of TCP/IP networks by reducing the number of packets that need to be sent (combining small packets).
An extension to enable data exchange during the initial TCP SYN handshake to reduce latency.

q: If a server is returning 504 Gateway Timeout, where is the issue likely located?
a: The issue is likely with an upstream server (the backend) taking too long to respond to the proxy/gateway.
